sections.heading: Disqualification when judge party; effect of attempted judicial acts
sections.text: 38.02Suggestion of disqualification; grounds; proceedings on suggestion and effect.38.03Waiver of grounds of disqualification by parties.38.04Sworn statement by judge holding himself or herself qualified.38.05Disqualification of judge on own motion

sections.heading: Suggestion of disqualification; grounds; proceedings on suggestion and effect.
sections.text: of disqualification; grounds; proceedings on suggestion and effect.

sections.heading: Waiver of grounds of disqualification by parties.
sections.text: 38.03 Waiver of grounds of disqualification by parties.—The parties to any cause, or their attorneys of record, may, by written stipulation filed in the cause, waive any of the grounds of disqualification named in s. 38.02 and such waiver shall be valid and binding as to orders previously entered as well as to future acts of the judge therein; provided, however, that nothing herein shall prevent a judge from disqualifying himself or herself of his or her own motion under s. 38.05. History.—s. 4, ch. 16053, 1933; CGL 1936 Supp. 4155(3); s. 207, ch. 95-147. sections.heading: Sworn statement by judge holding himself or herself qualified.
sections.text: statement by judge holding himself or herself qualified.

sections.heading: Disqualification of judge on own motion.
sections.text: 38.05 Disqualification of judge on own motion.—Any judge may of his or her own motion disqualify himself or herself where, to the judge’s own knowledge, any of the grounds for a suggestion of disqualification, as named in s. 38.02, exist. The failure of a judge to so disqualify himself or herself under this section shall not be assignable as error or subject to review. History.—s. 6, ch. 16053, 1933; CGL 1936 Supp. 4155(5); s. 6, ch. 63-559; s. 209, ch. 95-147. sections.heading: Power to punish contempts.
sections.text: 38.22 Power to punish contempts.—Every court may punish contempts against it whether such contempts be direct, indirect, or constructive, and in any such proceeding the court shall proceed to hear and determine all questions of law and fact. History.—s. 1, Nov. 23, 1828; RS 975; GS 1345; RGS 2534; CGL 4161; s. 1, ch. 23004, 1945; s. 4, ch. 73-334. sections.heading: Contempt defined.
sections.text: 38.23 Contempt defined.—A refusal to obey any legal order, mandate or decree, made or given by any judge relative to any of the business of the court, after due notice thereof, is a contempt, punishable accordingly. History.—s. 2, Nov. 23, 1828; RS 976; GS 1346; RGS 2535; CGL 4162; s. 8, ch. 2013-25.
